activities.name: curiosity undercover
activities.headline: uncover meaning and dig deeper
activities.content:
## objective:
strengthen your ability to stay curious longer—without jumping to conclusions or easy answers.
## instructions:
1. pair up participants and explain they are both undercover agents investigating a seemingly normal situation.
2. give them a simple everyday scene (e.g., someone watering a plant, a missing sock, a cat staring at a wall). their only investigative tool is the word “why.”
3. take turns asking only “why” questions that build on each other.
   - why is the plant indoors?
   - why do people keep plants inside their homes?
   - why do homes exist?
4. keep going until one of these natural endings occurs:
   - someone laughs out loud
   - one person says, “i’ve never thought about that before”
   - you hit a deep or weird question and agree to pause
   - you accidentally invent a conspiracy theory or philosophical truth
   - you decide you’ve reached the origin of the universe
## debrief
reflecting on how it felt to follow curiosity without resolution.
## optional
share your favorite “why moment” with the group.

activities.name: story threads
activities.headline: weave metaphors into shared meaning
activities.content:
## objective:
reflect on personal strengths and roles through symbolic metaphors to open with warmth and connection.
## instructions:
1. form a large circle or online group.
2. invite each person to introduce themselves: name, role, and what excites them most about their work
3. prompt them to reflect on their strongest contribution to a learning ecosystem
4. share symbolic examples to inspire reflection:
   - a deep-rooted oak
   - a resilient cactus
   - a sprawling banyan tree
   - water (flow, flexibility)
   - fire (passion, energy)
   - earth (grounding, stability)
   - air (openness, expansion)
5. ask each participant to select a metaphor that represents them.
6. in miro (or physically), have them place their metaphor visually in a shared space.
7. invite popcorn-style sharing to notice patterns and themes.
## optional:
close with a 2-minute self-assessment or reflective journaling on their metaphor and role.

activities.name: mirror match
activities.headline: find your twin without words
activities.content:
## objective:
warm up the group and spark playfulness by tapping into memory, movement, and shared meaning.
## instructions:
explain the game as an online version of the card game memory but with people. participants will try to find their match without words.

activities.name: swap perspectives
activities.headline: see decisions from all angles
activities.content:
## objective:
encourage participants to consider different viewpoints by stepping into the shoes of various stakeholders affected by a real-world business decision.
## instructions:
1. set the scene: share a prompt about a company that opened a new HQ by demolishing a local community center.
2. distribute stakeholder role cards (CEO, local business owner, employee, sustainability officer, local resident, tech investor, city official, environmental activist).
3. small group discussion: reflect on what your character is feeling, their hopes/fears/values, and how they’d describe the impact.
4. whole group debrief: discuss how stepping into someone else’s shoes shifted views.
5. optional twist: swap roles and repeat a mini-round.

activities.name: game of assumptions
activities.headline: play with bias and gain insights
activities.content:
## objective:
use playful debate to explore how wrong assumptions can shape our beliefs, helping participants become more aware of the limits of their own knowledge and stay open to other perspectives.
## instructions:
1. warm-up reflection: ask participants to write an assumption they’ve held that turned out to be wrong on a post-it note.
2. explain the activity: use a wheel of random assumptions to assign statements.
3. prepare your defense: each person gets a few minutes to prepare a 1-minute defense of their assumption, even if they don’t agree with it.
4. play the game: one person defends (1 min), others challenge (2 min). rotate roles.
5. group reflection: discuss what surprised you, whether wrong assumptions felt believable, and how it felt to let go of being right.
6. optional closing: introduce intellectual humility and encourage practicing it.

activities.name: ball relay
activities.headline: team coordination meets paper frenzy
activities.content:
## objective:
work together in lines to move a ball from the front to the back of the team using only paper—fast, fun, and full of teamwork chaos.
## materials:
1 lightweight ball per team (ping pong ball, crumpled paper, soft toy ball, etc.), 1 A4 sheet of paper per person
## instructions:
1. form teams of 10–20 people and have each team stand in a single file line.
2. give each person one sheet of paper.
3. the person at the front starts with the ball on their paper.
4. the team’s task: pass the ball to the back of the line using only their paper sheets as a track or channel. no hands can touch the ball directly.
5. if the ball drops, start again from the point of the drop.
6. first team to get their ball to the last person wins!

activities.name: soundscapes of the future
activities.headline: conduct tomorrow's ideas through sound
activities.content:
## objective:
co-create an auditory collage that represents visions of responsible futures.
## instructions:
1. divide into sections of 20–30 people.
2. assign each group a theme (e.g., sustainability, justice, ethics, play, innovation).
3. ask them to create a sound or rhythm (claps, stomps, snaps, chants) that represents that theme.
4. conduct the whole group like an orchestra.

activities.name: emoji charades
activities.headline: embody ideas with just faces
activities.content:
## objective:
act out emotions or abstract ideas in teams using only facial expressions and body language.
## instructions:
1. form teams of 10–15 people.
2. call out an emotion or concept (e.g., Imposter syndrome, Quarter-life crisis, Coffee addiction, Joy when WiFi works, Deadline panic).
3. teams have 30 seconds to create a frozen emoji tableau that captures the prompt.
4. on the count of 3: all teams reveal their poses.
5. applaud the most creative or relatable ones.
## optional twist:
have the crowd vote with applause or give fun awards (e.g., “Most Dramatic,” “Most Accurate”).

activities.name: memory game
activities.headline: challenge your brain with rapid recall
activities.content:
## objective:
practice working memory with a sequence of number and color combinations.
## instructions:
1. share a combination of numbers on a screen.
2. explain participants that you will share, then hide and then they have to remember and share the sequence.
3. increase difficulty by increasing numbers, then colors, then colors + numbers.

activities.name: solution mashup
activities.headline: fuse concepts to spark innovation
activities.content:
## objective:
encourage participants to combine unrelated business concepts and synthesize them into an innovative solution, fostering creativity and the ability to see connections between different ideas.
## instructions:
1. set the scene: explain that each team will receive two business concepts that may seem unrelated and their job is to combine them into a brand new service or product.
2. distribute concept cards: give each team (3–4 people) two random business concept cards.
3. group ideation: brainstorm ways the two concepts could be combined, design a service/product that adds value, consider what problem it solves.
4. present mashups: invite each team to pitch their solution quickly (max 60 seconds).
5. whole group debrief: reflect on what surprised you and how working with constraints helped or challenged your team.

activities.name: massive mingle
activities.headline: move, meet, share, repeat
activities.content:
## objective:
rapidly form connections while discussing meaningful topics.
## instructions:
1. set upbeat music.
2. participants walk around freely. when the music stops, pair up and respond to a prompt.
3. prompts include:
   - What’s a business practice you’d love your students to disrupt?
   - What’s one classroom rule or norm that deserves a second look?
   - What’s one thing you hope your students never forget, even if they forget the syllabus?
   - What’s a leadership trait we overvalue in business?
   - What’s a business buzzword that needs redefinition?
4. repeat 3–4 times.

activities.name: how has play shaped you?
activities.headline: explore identity through playful reflection
activities.content:
## objective:
invite connection and reflection by linking personal hobbies to perceptions of play.
## instructions:
1. form a large circle or online group.
2. invite each participant to introduce themselves: name, role, organization, and one hobby that has reshaped the way they think about play.
3. encourage brief, focused sharing to keep energy moving.
4. as themes emerge, lightly highlight interesting connections between hobbies and professional perspectives.
## optional:
note common threads or surprising contrasts on a board or shared doc to revisit later.

activities.name: world map
activities.headline: shape ideas into living models
activities.content:
## objective:
embody complex ideas in playful, physical forms.
## instructions:
1. ask people to walk around the room and then say a number to make groups; end with groups of 8–10 people.
2. you will say a prompt for teams to create a living picture that embodies it:
   - a classroom that teaches ethical leadership
   - a moment where business-as-usual was challenged
   - the opposite of “responsible management”
   - the classroom we never want to see again
   - a business model that values care as much as capital
3. walk the “gallery”; invite a few to explain theirs.

activities.name: character roll call
activities.headline: playful introduction to turn your voice up
activities.content:
## objective:
spark laughter and loosen up the room by encouraging playful self-expression and creative risk-taking.
## instructions:
1. prepare a slide or image board with a mix of well-known characters (e.g., mickey mouse, darth vader, shrek, moana, minion, yoda, elsa).
2. explain that each person will introduce themselves: name, role, and one thing they’re curious about today— but using the voice or style of one of the characters shown.
3. once a character voice has been used, it cannot be repeated.
4. go around the room or call on volunteers.
5. encourage playful commitment.
## optional twist:
after everyone has gone, invite a few to guess who was impersonating whom.

activities.name: cheerleader
activities.headline: from rivals to raving fans
activities.content:
## objective:
build energy and playful competition through escalating rounds of rock-paper-scissors.
## instructions:
1. everyone starts by facing off with someone nearby in rock-paper-scissors.
2. whoever loses becomes the winner’s cheerleader: clapping, chanting their name, or doing silent gestures.
3. the winner moves on to battle another winner, now with a mini fan club.
4. repeat until there are only two final players, each with half the room cheering them on.
5. have the crowd cheer for their champion, and do one last epic battle on stage.
